lg.l: In the next Place I shall present you with a very Notable and Remarkable Prophecy relating to these Times. It is said to be one of the Prophesies of our British Merlin, above 1000 Years ago, and said to be translated about the end of the Reign of K Henry VII. Printed at London by Johan Haukins, in the Year 1530. Page 39th. of Merlin's Prophesies. I have given it you in the old Orthography.

div.lg:
Seven and Ten addyd to Nyne,
Of France hir Woe thys is the Sygne,
Teamys Rivere twys y-frozen,
Walke sans wetynge Shoes ne Hozen,
Then comyth foorthe, Ich understonde,
From Towne of Stoffe to fattyn Lond,
An herdie Chiftan, woe the Morne
To France, that evere he was Borne;
Then shall the Fyshe beweyle his Bosse,
Nor shall Grin Berris make up the Losse.
Young Symnele shall again miscarrye,
And Norway's Pryd again shall Marreye,
And from the Tree where Blosums fele,
Ripe Fruit shall come, and all is wele;
Reaums shall Dance hond in hond,
And it shall be merye in old Inglond,
Then old Inglond shall be no more,
And no Man shall be sorry therefore,
Geryon shall have three Heads again,
Geryon shall have three Heads again,Till Hapsburgh maketh them but twain.
\ENDNOTES:\
Now having given you the Prophecy in the Character and Stile it was given me, without Alteration, I shall give you a short Explanation of the same.
Seven and Ten makes Seventeen; which is thought to signifie Seventeen Hundred, and added to Nine, 1709. beginning at the first of Jan.
om.
om.
This same Year the River Thames was twice frozen over, so that Men went over as we may say Dry-shod.
om.
The Chieftain, or General, that is signified by the Town of Stuff to fatten Land, may be understood of the D. of Marlborough,
for in some Countries they use to throw Marle on the Ground to fatten it, and make it Fertile; and Borough every one knows to signifie a Town.
om.
By the Fish may be understood the Dolphin, or Dauphin of France,
and he bewailing his Bosse, may signifie the D. of Burgundy his Son, for Bosse is an old English Word for Hump-Shoulders, as that Duke is known to be,
and it seems to mean that he shall be either Over-come or Slain.
By Green Berries, we may imagine it to mean the D. of Berry, who shall neither have Valour nor Fortune to supply the Loss.
By Young Simnell, you may guess it to be the Pretender, which if he offers to Invade us again, shall miscarry.
There was one Lambert Simnel, I think, did Personate the Son of K. Edward the IVth.
As for Norway's Pride, I leave the Reader to judge as he thinks fit. I should be glad to see it according as I understand it.
Now Reaums was an old Name for Kingdoms, as now we call them Realms,
and their Dancing hand in hand must undoubtedly signifie the Union of the Two Kingdoms,
for he says Old-England shall be no more; meaning, that England and Scotland, as I take it, shall be call'd by the Name of Great-Britain.
om.
om.
Then for Geryon,
it is said he was a King of Spain, whom Hercules slew:
He was feigned by the Poets to have Three Heads, which our Prophecy says he shall have again.
om.
This is wonderfully come to pass;
for Portugal being properly a part of Spain, there is one King, and in Spain it self there is two Contending Rivals,
Charles and Philip.
And when he says Hapsburgh shall make them but Twain or Two; This is plain that Charles the IIId. King of Spain, now contending with Philip D. of Anjou, is Lineally descended from the Count of Hapsburgh, Founder of the Austrian Family;
so that the meaning of making the Three Heads but Two again, must needs be, That K. Charles the IIId. with the Assistance of his good Friends, shall force Philip out of the Kingdom of Spain, sending him into France again by the Weeping-Cross.
And thus I have given you the Prophecy or Prediction of old Merlin, and the Explanation of it, according to my Judgment, and leave every Reader to make what further Interpretation of it he can.
